citation.article-title: Advenella incenata gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel member of the Alcaligenaceae, isolated from various clinical samples.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Advenella (Ad.ven.el′la. L. n. advena a stranger, a foreigner; L. dim. ending -ella; N.L. fem. n. Advenella the little stranger, referring to the fact that the source of these unusual organisms is unknown).
Gram-negative, small (1–2 μm), rod-shaped or coccoid cells that occur alone, in pairs or in short chains.
On nutrient agar, colonies are flat or slightly convex with smooth margins.
Oxidase and catalase activity but no β-galactosidase activity is observed.
Additional biochemical characteristics are given above (see Results and Discussion).
The following fatty acid components are present in significant amounts: 12 : 0, 16 : 0, 17 : 0 cyclo, 18 : 1ω7c, SF2 and SF3.
The DNA G+C content ranges from 53·6 to 57·7 mol%.
Strains of this genus have been isolated from various human and veterinary clinical samples.
The type species is Advenella incenata.
